newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait parliament rejects Islamist ban on concerts.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait parliament rejects Islamist ban on concerts.

text.p: Kuwait's parliament on Tuesday rejected an Islamist bill banning concerts and fashion shows that fail to comply with the teachings of Islam.
After winning a first round of voting last week, the bill attracted 20 votes out of 44 in the final vote on Tuesday.
Islamists object to women singing to an audience that includes men or vice-versa as well as to women dressing attractively around men who are not close relatives.

Politicians have said the government had campaigned to thwart the bill. Officials said there was no need for such a measure since the conservative Gulf Arab state already observes Islamic teachings in all areas.
"There is no need for such a law that would only give a wrong impression about Kuwait," said an official. He did not elaborate.
Islamists have slammed the government for allowing concerts after stopping them for five years following the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait.
The proposed bill imposed a six-month jail term and a fine of not less than 5,000 dinars ($16,500) on violaters of the ban.
The government expressed willingness to discuss rules governing such functions with a parliamentary panel.
Kuwait already bans public dancing and alcohol. Discotheques, once tolerated, were closed in the 1980s.
